;;前南卡罗来纳州州长妮基·哈利 (Nikki Haley) 和佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯 (Ron DeSantis) 在 2024 年美国总统第二场共和党候选人辩论中互相注视2023 年 9 月 27 日在美国加利福尼亚州西米谷罗纳德·里根总统图书馆举行的竞选活动。路透社/迈克·布莱克/档案照片;
;

;唐纳德·特朗普的共和党总统提名竞争对手对以色列发表了强硬言论- 哈马斯在周三的辩论中发生冲突，承诺无条件支持以色列，并攻击民主党总统乔·拜登对危机的处理。

;

;当被问及他们将向以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡传达什么信息时，佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯表示，“我将用内塔尼亚胡的昵称告诉比比，“彻底解决哈马斯这些屠夫的工作，他们是恐怖分子”。

;

;前联合国大使尼基·黑利（Nikki Haley），她在竞选中下了很大的赌注她在外交政策方面指责拜登敦促以色列考虑暂停人道主义援助。

;

;“我们最不需要做的就是告诉以色列该做什么，”她说。 “我们唯一应该做的就是支持他们并消灭哈马斯。”

;

;南卡罗来纳州参议员蒂姆·斯科特表示，拜登应该对哈马斯的支持者伊朗进行直接打击，以报复对美军的袭击伊朗代理人在叙利亚和伊拉克的人员。在美国;对武器进行打击;后不久，他发表了讲话五角大楼称该设施被伊朗军队使用。

;

;“如果你想有所作为，就不能继续对叙利亚的仓库进行袭击，”他说。 “你实际上必须砍掉蛇的头，而蛇的头是伊朗，而不仅仅是代理人。”

;

;关于以色列与哈马斯冲突的讨论是在辩论的开场部分之后进行的。候选人被要求证明自己是共和党的旗手，而不是特朗普，后者在全国民意调查中明显领先。

;

;这位前总统第三次没有出席共和党的竞选活动。辩论，而不是在附近举行;一场竞争对手的活动;，他再次建议共和党应该取消未来的辩论。

;

;特朗普表示，“共和党建制派是时候停止浪费时间和资源了”，并补充说这场辩论“不值得观看”。

; >;

;德桑蒂斯批评特朗普缺席了在他们共同家乡佛罗里达州举行的这次活动，并建议该党在周二的非年度选举中表现不佳应归咎于特朗普。

;

; “他说共和党人会厌倦胜利，”德桑蒂斯说。 “好吧，我们昨晚看到了 - 我厌倦了共和党的失败！”

;

;黑莉提出了更为温和的批评。

;

;“每个人都想谈论特朗普总统。我看得出来我认为他是在正确的时间出现的正确的总统，”她说。 “我认为他现在不是合适的总统。”

;

;距离爱荷华州首次共和党州提名竞选还有两个多月的时间，特朗普的竞争对手可能没有更多机会破坏他的领先优势。尽管他受到多项刑事起诉，但他在民意调查中仍受到共和党选民的支持。

;

;77 岁的特朗普竭尽全力否认黑利和德桑蒂斯成为直接目标，而是将重点放在他预计将与黑利和德桑蒂斯重赛上。拜登，80 岁，2024 年 11 月 5 日。

;

;在之前的两场电视辩论中，51 岁的海莉和 45 岁的德桑蒂斯一直小心翼翼地避免对特朗普过于严厉，因为担心疏远他的如果他们想最终在 7 月份获得共和党提名，他们就需要他们的支持。

;

;对突破时刻的需要促使几位候选人向其他辩手开火。

;

;在讨论是否禁止 TikTok 时，企业家维韦克·拉马斯瓦米 (Vivek Ramaswamy) 有一次指出，海莉的女儿使用该应用程序，促使海莉警告他不要再提及她的女儿。

;

;“你就是人渣”。她嘀咕道。

;

;拉马斯瓦米，支持;孤立主义者; 外交政策方针，还表示将切断对乌克兰的援助，称总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基是“穿着工装裤的喜剧演员”。

;

;作为回应，黑利表示俄罗斯和中国领导人对拉马斯瓦米可能成为美国总统的想法“垂涎欲滴”。

;

;随着黑莉在之前的几次辩论中表现越来越强，黑莉和德桑蒂斯的竞争也愈演愈烈，两人也发生了冲突，双方都指责对方作为州长过于欢迎中国投资。

;

;除了推动海外采取更强有力的应对措施外，候选人还誓言要惩罚国内的哈马斯同情者。

;

;被问及亲巴勒斯坦问题针对大学校园里激增的集会，斯科特表示，他将扣留任何未能防止反犹太主义的大学的联邦资助。

;

;德桑蒂斯承诺将驱逐任何表示支持哈马斯的学生。

;

;他说：“如果你是持有学生签证的外国人，并且你与哈马斯有共同的事业，我将取消你的签证，并将你送回家。” “没有提出任何问题。”

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 10:55:03 +0800 Seven Nashville officers placed on administrative duty after shooting manifesto leakhttps://reuters.com/article/tennessee-shooting-manifesto/seven-nashville-officers-placed-on-administrative-duty-after-shooting-manifesto-leak-idUSKBN32405F

;

;田纳西州纳什维尔市的七名警察已被安排执行行政职责，作为其部门对“泄露”事件进行调查的一部分宣言”是今年早些时候在基督教小学杀害六人的枪手留下的文字。

;

;纳什维尔大都会警察局 (MNPD) 在周三的一份简短声明中表示，这些警官的行政任务是“声明补充说，所有七人都保留“全部警察权力”。发言人布鲁克·里斯(Brooke Reese)表示，他们继续领取工资。没有透露这七名警官的姓名，也没有透露他们与泄密调查的联系。

;

;里斯说，这些警官的调任于周一生效，即该部门主动启动调查的当天。 。纳什维尔市长弗雷迪·奥康奈尔也要求进行调查。

;

;自;圣约学校惨案; 犯罪嫌疑人留下了一份“宣言”和其他文字，但该材料的内容被调查人员封存。 3 月 27 日的袭击中，三名 9 岁学生和三名成年人被杀。嫌疑人在现场被警察击毙。

;

;周一，三页文字的图像被发布在播客“Louder with Crowder”的网站上后开始在社交媒体上流传，该播客声称“独家获得”这些照片。

;

;播客主持人史蒂夫·克劳德周二在接受纳什维尔记者采访时表示，泄露的材料来自匿名来源，其中包括一名参与此案的侦探。

;

; >;

;枪击事件发生后数小时内，警察局长约翰·德雷克 (John Drake) 确认嫌疑人为奥黛丽·伊丽莎白·黑尔 (Audrey Elizabeth Hale)，她是该校的一名 28 岁前学生，局长称她为“变性人”。很快就有消息称，在枪击事件发生前的几个月里，黑尔一直使用艾登这个名字，并在社交媒体上使用男性代词。

;

;德雷克当时表示，黑尔曾;在医生的治疗下;因“情绪障碍”而收集了一系列物品持有枪支，可能因小时候必须上圣约学校而怀有“一些怨恨”。但警方从未提供确凿的动机。

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 10:55:03 +0800 Hollywood actors reach tentative deal with studios to end strikehttps://reuters.com/article/television-actors/hollywood-actors-reach-tentative-deal-with-studios-to-end-strike-idUSKBN324025
;;2023-11-09T01:55:34Z;
;;
;;SAG-AFTRA 成员吉姆·库利克 (Jim Kulick) 和其他 SAG-AFTRA 成员在罢工第 100 天走在纠察线上时的反应， 2023 年 10 月 20 日，美国加利福尼亚州洛杉矶派拉蒙影城外。路透社/Mario Anzuoni/档案照片;
;

;好莱坞演员周三与主要制片厂达成临时协议，以解决第二个问题;震惊娱乐业的两次罢工; 今年，随着流媒体电视时代工人们要求更高的工资。

;

;SAG-AFTRA 工会在其谈判委员会一致投票通过后在一份声明中表示，为期 118 天的停工将在午夜过后正式结束。支持该协议。

;

;该组织的全国委员会将于周五考虑该协议，工会表示将在会议后公布更多细节。

;

;SAG-AFTRA 成员离开了工会7月中旬，工会要求提高最低工资、提高流媒体服务收入的份额，并防止被人工智能（AI）生成的“数字复制品”取代。

;

;工会谈判代表达成了初步协议与代表华特迪士尼的电影电视制片人联盟 (AMPTP) 达成新合同 ;(DIS.N);，Netflix ;(NFLX.O);以及其他媒体公司。

;

;AMPTP 代表没有立即回复置评请求。

;

;这一突破意味着好莱坞可以自 5 月份以来首次全面投入制作，一旦工会成员将在未来几周内投票批准该协议。

;

;“我松了一口气，”演员范妮·格兰德在接受采访时说道。 “对于这个行业的大多数人来说，这真的很困难，尤其是有色人种。事实上，我们没有那么多机会。我们不是在银行里存了几个月钱的大名人。我真的希望这是一笔公平的交易。”

;

;演员杰西卡·佩恩表示，她“深感感激，谨慎乐观，并准备好工作。”

;

;周三早些时候，有关潜在协议的消息已传遍好莱坞，这给那些花了数周时间在纽约和洛杉矶的工作室办公室外而不是在片场进行纠察的演员们带来了希望。

;

;“初步的讨论是投票即将到来，”最出名的阿努 (Anu) 拉蒂·古普塔 (Rati Gupta) 说。在哥伦比亚广播公司的喜剧《生活大爆炸》中。 “今天几个小时以来，我的心一直在狂跳。”

;

;演员们也有与 ;电影和电视作家;，他们认为，随着流媒体的普及，工薪阶层演员的报酬已经减少，使得在洛杉矶和纽约等城市很难赚取生活工资。流媒体电视剧并没有提供演员在广播电视鼎盛时期享有的相同剩余报酬。

;

;演员们也对人工智能的最新进展感到震惊，他们担心这可能会导致制片厂在不知情的情况下操纵他们的肖像。许可或用数字图像替换人类演员。

;

;;乔治·克鲁尼;和其他一线明星表达了对低级别演员的声援，并敦促工会领导层，包括美国演员工会主席和《保姆》演员弗兰·德雷舍，达成一项解决方案。

;

;当美国编剧工会 (WGA) 在春季发起罢工时，许多电影和电视剧都被关闭。虽然 WGA 成员于 9 月下旬恢复编写剧本，但 SAG-AFTRA 持续停工导致许多制作陷入困境。

;

;据米尔肯研究所估计，此次中断给加州造成了超过 60 亿美元的产出损失。< /p>;

;由于工作量很少，许多道具师、服装设计师和其他剧组成员都在努力维持生计。批准拍摄许可的组织 FilmLA 报告称，10 月 29 日当周的剧本制作量比去年同期下降了 77%。

;

;好莱坞罢工发生在其他备受瞩目的事件发生之际。工作行动。美国汽车工人联合会;最近结束了;为期六周的罢工在底特律汽车制造商。教师、护士和医护人员也罢工了。

;

;好莱坞的停工迫使广播网络通过重播、游戏节目和真人秀来填补秋季节目阵容。这也导致电影制片厂推迟了《沙丘：第二部分》等大片的上映，因为引人注目的演员无法宣传它们。

;

;其他主要电影，包括最新的《碟中谍》系列电影和迪士尼的《碟中谍》系列电影。经典动画《白雪公主》的真人翻拍被推迟到 2025 年。

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 10:25:03 +0800 Takeaways from the third 2024 Republican presidential debatehttps://reuters.com/article/usa-election-republicans-debate-takeaway/takeaways-from-the-third-2024-republican-presidential-debate-idUSKBN32403S
;;2023-11-09T02:02:36Z;
;;
;;前南卡罗来纳州州长 Nikki Haley 对前生物技术高管 Vivek Ramaswamy 对她在乌克兰战争问题上的立场的批评作出反应，佛罗里达州州长 Ron DeSantis 正在聆听2023 年 11 月 8 日，在美国佛罗里达州迈阿密艾德丽安·阿什特表演艺术中心，由 NBC 新闻主办的 2024 年美国总统竞选第三场共和党候选人美国总统辩论上。REUTERS/Mike Segar;;

;五位候选人齐聚一堂，试图阻止唐纳德·特朗普争夺;2024 年共和党总统提名;周三在迈阿密举行;党的第三次辩论; 而前总统在城里举行了单独的竞选集会。

;

;以下是这场辩论的一些要点：

;

;在一场刺痛的;在民主党手中遭遇一系列选举失败;，候选人在辩论舞台上发泄了不满。

;

;“我厌倦了共和党的失败，”佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯说道。

;

;德桑蒂斯长期以来一直将他去年在佛罗里达州的成功连任与共和党在过去几次选举中的挫折进行了对比，包括特朗普在 2020 年落败。当天早些时候，他的竞选团队辩称，支持特朗普会导致候选人在肯塔基州州长竞选中失去席位，共和党人丹尼尔·卡梅伦在肯塔基州州长选举中输给了民主党人安迪·贝希尔。

;

;周三共和党人我们还因;投票问题的成功而感到痛苦俄亥俄州;将堕胎权写入州宪法，弗吉尼亚州失去了州立法控制权。

;

;企业家维韦克·拉马斯瓦米 (Vivek Ramaswamy) 指责共和党全国委员会主席罗娜·麦克丹尼尔 (Ronna McDaniel) ，而不是特朗普，因为该党最近的表现。

;

;“我们已经成为失败者的政党，”他感叹道。 “我们的党内必须承担责任。”

;

;麦克丹尼尔是特朗普精心挑选的 2017 年共和党全国委员会主席，该委员会是周三辩论的赞助商。

;

;拉马斯瓦米当晚早些时候攻击了前联合国大使尼基·黑利、德桑蒂斯，甚至辩论主持人克里斯汀·韦尔克，显然是为了转移人们对他的支持率较高的对手的注意力。

;

;在关于以色列冲突的交流中拉马斯瓦米警告说，舞台上的两位领先候选人海莉和德桑蒂斯可能会将美国拖入一场血腥战争，同时还提到了德桑蒂斯在靴子内穿增高鞋以显得更高的猜测。

;

;“你想要吗？”穿着三英寸高跟鞋的迪克·切尼？因为今晚舞台上有他们两个，”他在提到海莉和德桑蒂斯时说道，同时引用了一位好战的共和党前副总统的名字。

;

;”它们是五英寸高的高跟鞋，除非我能穿着它们跑步，否则我不会穿它们，”海莉后来反驳道。“它们不是时尚宣言，而是弹药。”

;

;民意调查显示，拉马斯瓦米正在努力重新获得选民和媒体的关注。

;

;除了猛烈抨击他的对手之外，他还表示 NBC 的韦尔克根本不应该主持辩论。

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 10:25:03 +0800 Fierce fighting in Gaza City; US says Palestinians must govern Gaza post-warhttps://reuters.com/article/israel-palestinians/fierce-fighting-in-gaza-city-us-says-palestinians-must-govern-gaza-post-war-idUSKBN32404A
;;2023-11-09T02:06:13Z;
;

;加沙城爆发巷战，哈马斯武装分子利用地道伏击以色列军队，美国称巴勒斯坦人必须治理战后的加沙，反驳以色列关于将无限期控制安全的言论。

;

;以色列军方表示，其部队已进入加沙市中心，哈马斯的主要堡垒和海滨飞地最大的城市，而该伊斯兰组织则表示，其武装分子造成了严重损失。

;

;哈马斯武装派别周三发布了一段视频，似乎显示加沙城被炸毁的建筑物旁边发生了激烈的巷战。

;

;据伊朗支持的哈马斯和独立的伊斯兰圣战激进组织的消息人士称，以色列坦克遭到哈马斯武装分子利用地下隧道进行伏击的猛烈抵抗。

;

;以色列袭击加沙是为了回应跨境哈马斯的袭击根据以色列统计，10 月 7 日袭击以色列南部，枪手杀害了 1,400 人，其中大部分是平民，并劫持了约 240 名人质。

;

;巴勒斯坦官员表示，截至周三，已有 10,569 人被杀，占 40%其中有孩子。以色列称有 33 名士兵被杀。

;

;随着以色列与哈马斯的战争进入第二个月，华盛顿已开始与以色列和阿拉伯领导人讨论加沙地带没有哈马斯统治的未来。

;

; >;

;虽然计划尚未出台，但美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯概述了华盛顿对被围困的沿海领土的期望。

;

;Donald Trump's leading rivals for the Republican presidential nomination sought to make the case for being their party's standard-bearer at the outset of Wednesday's Republican debate, with time running out to disrupt the former president's march toward another White House bid.

;

;Florida Governor Ron DeSantis criticized Trump for skipping their debate, which took place in their shared home state of Florida, and suggested that the party's poor showing in Tuesday's off-year elections should be laid at Trump's feet.

;

;"He said Republicans were gonna get tired of winning," DeSantis said. "Well, we saw last night - I'm sick of Republicans losing!"

;

;Former UN Ambassador Nikki Haley offered a more muted critique.

;

;"Everybody wants to talk about President Trump. I can tell you that I think he was the right president at the right time," she said. "I don't think he's the right president now."

;

;With the first Republican state nominating contest in Iowa little more than two months away, Trump's rivals may not have many more chances to derail the commanding lead he holds among Republican voters in public opinion polling, despite his multiple criminal indictments.

;

;For the third time, the frontrunner did not show up for the debate, instead holding ;a rival event; close by.

;

;Haley, 51, in third place nationally, has grown stronger as she seeks to dislodge DeSantis, 45, from his distant second place.

;

;Trump, 77, has done his best to deny Haley and DeSantis a direct target, instead focusing on what he expects to be a rematch with Democratic President Joe Biden, 80.

;

;In the two previous televised debates, Haley and DeSantis had been careful not to come down on Trump too hard for fear of alienating his supporters, whose backing they will need if they are to ultimately capture the Republican nomination in July.

;

;The election is almost exactly a year away - Nov. 5, 2024.

;

;Trump held ;a campaign rally; a few miles away in the heavily Hispanic city of Hialeah. Hispanics are a voting group both parties will be courting heavily.

;

;Haley, a former South Carolina governor, was coming off two strong debate performances and has been the only Republican besides Trump to show recent momentum in early nominating states such as Iowa and New Hampshire.

;

;With the month-old Israeli-Hamas conflict making headlines, the debate afforded an opportunity for Haley to flash her foreign policy credentials.

;

;While DeSantis and Haley hope to capitalize on strong debate performances, the debate could well fail to offer a turning point in what has been a race dominated by Trump from the start.

;

;The three other debate participants - former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, businessman Vivek Ramaswamy and US Senator Tim Scott - sought to assert their relevance and find a path forward.

;

;Ramaswamy was expected to use the debate stage to promote ;his non-interventionist foreign policy; as he seeks to position himself as the least likely candidate to wade into a foreign war.

;

;NuScale Power ;(SMR.N); said on Wednesday it has agreed with a power group in Utah to terminate the company's small modular reactor project, dealing a blow to US ambitions for a wave of nuclear energy to fight climate change and sending NuScale's shares down 20%.

;

;In 2020, the Department of Energy approved $1.35 billion over 10 years for the plant, known as the Carbon Free Power Project, subject to congressional appropriations. NuScale has received about $600 million from the department since 2014 to support the design, licensing and siting of the project.

;

;NuScale had planned to develop the six-reactor 462 megawatt project with the Utah Associated Municipal Power Systems (UAMPS) and launch it in 2030, but several towns pulled out of the project as costs rose.

;

;John Hopkins, NuScale's president and CEO, said in a release that the company will continue with its other domestic and international customers to bring American small modular reactor (SMR) technology to market and increase the US nuclear manufacturing bases.

;

;NuScale hopes to build SMRs in Romania, Kazakhstan, Poland and Ukraine. Critics have warned that Russia's takeover of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in Ukraine -- along with repeated shelling near it, power cuts, and perils to the plant's water cooling resources -- means that reactors, which can release toxic, radioactive materials when disasters strike, should not be built in the region.

;

;NuScale's Utah plant was expected to be the first SMR to win a license from the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission for construction. But NuScale said it appeared unlikely the project will have enough subscription to continue toward deployment.

;

;NuScale said in January the target price for power from the plant was $89 per megawatt hour, up 53% from the previous estimate of $58 per MWh, raising concerns about customers' willingness to pay.

;

;An Energy Department spokesperson said it was unfortunate news, but added, "We believe the work accomplished to date on CFPP will be valuable for future nuclear energy projects.

;

;"While not every project is guaranteed to succeed, DOE remains committed to doing everything we can to deploy these technologies to combat the climate crisis and increase access to clean energy," the spokesperson said.

;

;Existing US nuclear plants, which are larger, provide nearly half of the virtually carbon-free power generated in the US

;

;SMRs are meant to fit new applications such as replacing shut coal plants and being located in remote communities.

;

;Backers have said the design was safer than today's reactors, but critics have said SMRs still produce hazardous nuclear waste.

;

;So far, only NuScale's SMR design has been approved by the NRC.

;

;The public US money for NuScale was awarded through a non-competitive funding vehicle that came before the energy and climate bills passed during the Biden administration.

;;An Israeli soldier gestures as military vehicles manoeuvre, amid the ongoing ground invasion against Palestinian Islamist group Hamas in the northern Gaza Strip, November 8, 2023. REUTERS/Ronen Zvulun/File Photo;
;

;Palestinians should govern Gaza once Israel ends its war against Hamas, the United States said on Wednesday, pushing back against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's idea that Israel would be responsible for security indefinitely.

;

;Hamas gunmen from Gaza burst through the border to Israel on Oct. 7 and killed 1,400 people, Israel says. Now a month later, Washington has begun discussing with Israeli and Arab leaders a future for the Gaza Strip without Hamas rule.

;

;While a plan has yet to emerge, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Wednesday outlined in the most comprehensive comments on the issue to date Washington's red lines and expectations for the besieged coastal territory.

;

;"No reoccupation of Gaza after the conflict ends. No attempt to blockade or besiege Gaza. No reduction in the territory of Gaza," Blinken said at a press conference in Tokyo.

;

;Blinken said there may be a need for "some transition period" at the end of the conflict, but that post-crisis governance in Gaza must include Palestinian voices.

;

;"It must include Palestinian-led governance and Gaza unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority."

;

;On Monday, Netanyahu told ABC News that ;Israel will "for an indefinite period"; have security responsibility of the enclave after the war. His comments appeared at odds with US officials who say Israel does not want to administer Gaza post-Hamas.

;

;"I think Israel will, for an indefinite period, will have the overall security responsibility because we've seen what happens when we don't have that security responsibility," Netanyahu said.

;

;Israeli officials ;have since tried to clarify; they do not intend to occupy Gaza after the war, but they have yet to articulate how they might ensure security without maintaining a military presence. Israel withdrew its forces from Gaza in 2005.

;

;The Palestinian Authority (PA), which exercises limited self-rule in parts of the Israeli-occupied West Bank, says Gaza, where Hamas has ruled since 2007, is an integral part of what it envisions for a future Palestinian state.

;

;But top officials including Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas say a PA return to Gaza must be accompanied by a political solution that ends Israel's occupation of territory it captured in the 1967 Middle East war.

;

;"(We) are not going to go to Gaza on an Israeli military tank," PA Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh told PBS this week. "We are going to go to Gaza as part of a solution that deals with the question of Palestine, that deals with occupation."

;

;Hamas took over Gaza after a brief civil war in 2007 with Abbas' Fatah party. Years of reconciliation talks between the rivals failed to reach a breakthrough for resuming PA administration of Gaza. The PA still pays for electricity, water and some civil servant salaries in Gaza.

;

;Since Oct. 7, more than 10,000 Palestinians have been killed in a relentless bombardment of the Gaza Strip - home to 2.3 million - by Israeli forces, say Palestinian health officials in Gaza. About 40% of those killed are children, they say.

;

;Arab states, which provide the PA with financial aid, have advocated for an immediate ceasefire but have shown reluctance to discuss a post-war status for Gaza. They say the focus should remain on stopping hostilities.

;

;But Blinken said the conversation about the future should take place now.

;

;"Because identifying the longer-term objectives and a pathway to get there will help shape our approach to addressing immediate needs," he said.

;

;Since conflict broke out, the Biden administration has reasserted its support for a solution based on Israeli and Palestinian states side by side but has yet to outline a path to reviving long-stalled peace talks, the last round of which broke down in 2014.

;

;UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres on Wednesday said "best-case scenario" would be a ;"hopefully re-invigorated" Palestinian Authority; assuming some political control over Gaza.

;

;White House spokesperson John Kirby said Washington and its partners were still discussing what a Gaza governance structure might look like.

;

;"We believe that the Palestinians should be in charge of their future and they should be the determining voice and factor in their future," he said.
